thread.title: Wisconsin nursing homes criticize new federal staffing rules
thread.title_full: Wisconsin nursing homes criticize new federal staffing rules

author: DAVID WAHLBERG dwahlberg@madison.com
title: Wisconsin nursing homes criticize new federal staffing rules
text:
“It will make nursing home care harder to access for the average person,” said Rene Eastman, vice president for policy and finance at LeadingAge Wisconsin, which represents nursing homes.
Under final rules announced by the Biden administration last month , nursing homes will have to provide at least 3 hours, 29 minutes of nursing care per resident each day, including at least 33 minutes by registered nurses and at least 2 hours, 27 minutes by nurse aides. An RN always will have to be on-site.

A consumer group applauded the move as an “ important first step in ensuring that all residents have their care needs met,” but pushed for higher staffing mandates .
Nursing home groups say the rules unfairly apply to all kinds of facilities , regardless of size and what kinds of residents they have . Bills before Congress would reduce the requirements .
On Friday, the American Health Care Association, the Texas Health Care Association and three nursing homes filed a lawsuit challenging the rules , saying they create “impossible-to-meet standards that will harm thousands of nursing homes and the vulnerable Americans they serve” and exceed the authority of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.
“It’s a simplistic approach to a really complex problem, dealing with labor availability and economics,” said Rick Abrams, CEO of the Wisconsin Health Care Association, which represents nursing homes.
